questions.article: Few new parents ______ that their baby will someday become an astronaut. Yet if Jerry L. Ross's parents had made this prediction when he was born in 1948, they would have been correct, for NASA selected him for the job in 1980.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: disagree

options.name: B
options.content: ignore

options.name: C
options.content: require

options.name: D
options.content: anticipate

questions.solution: 这段文字讲述了很少有新手父母会预料（anticipate）他们的孩子有朝一日会成为一名宇航员。然而，如果杰瑞·L·罗斯（Jerry L.Ross）的父母在他1948年出生时做出这样的预测，那他们就说对了，因为美国国家航空航天局（NASA）在1980年选中了他从事这份工作。 题目是让选择一个最符合逻辑和精确的词或短语来完成文本。 选项A“disagree”（不同意），与文意不符，这里不是说父母不同意孩子会成为宇航员，A选项错误。 选项B“ignore”（忽视），也不符合语境，不是说父母忽视孩子会成为宇航员这件事，B选项不合适。 选项C“require”（要求），文中没有提及父母对孩子有成为宇航员的要求，C选项不正确。 选项D“anticipate”（预料、预期），能够准确表达出很少有父母会预料到孩子未来会成为宇航员的意思，与后文形成对比，D选项正确。 所以正确答案是D。文中的实体信息有：杰瑞·L·罗斯（Jerry L.Ross）、美国国家航空航天局（NASA）。

questions.article:
The following text is from Kenneth Grahame's 1908 novel The Wind in the Willows. The Rat is looking for the Mole, his friend, in the woods.

[The Rat] had patiently hunted through the wood for an hour or more, when at last to his joy he heard a little answering cry. Guiding himself by the sound, he made his way through the gathering darkness to the foot of an old beech tree.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “guiding” most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Withdrawing

options.name: B
options.content: Presenting

options.name: C
options.content: Instructing

options.name: D
options.content: Steering

questions.solution: 这段文字选自肯尼斯·格雷厄姆（Kenneth Grahame）1908年的小说《柳林风声》（The Wind in the Willows），文中描述老鼠在树林里寻找他的朋友鼹鼠，它已经耐心地在树林里搜寻了一个小时或更久，最后终于高兴地听到了一声小小的回应叫声。老鼠循着声音（guiding himself by the sound），在渐浓的黑暗中走到了一棵老山毛榉树脚下。 题目是问文中“guiding”这个词最接近的意思。 选项A“Withdrawing”（撤回、撤退），与文中老鼠循着声音前进的意思相反，A选项错误。 选项B“Presenting”（呈现、展示），不能表达出老鼠依据声音来行动的意思，B选项不合适。 选项C“Instructing”（指示、指导），通常指人对人的教导或指示，在这里形容老鼠依据声音行动不恰当，C选项不正确。 选项D“Steering”（引导、驾驶），可以形象地表示老鼠根据声音来指引自己的方向，与原文语境相符，D选项正确。 所以正确答案是D。文中的实体信息有：肯尼斯·格雷厄姆的1908年小说《柳林风声》、老鼠（The Rat）、鼹鼠（the Mole）、树林（the woods）、老山毛榉树（an old beech tree）。

questions.article: Alfred Nobel intended for the Nobel Prize to be an award honoring those who have contributed “the greatest benefit to mankind.” Indeed, the work of Richard Laurence Millington Synge represented a significant ______ the field of chemistry, and in 1952 he was among those awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for “their invention of partition chromatography.”
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: controversy in

options.name: B
options.content: exposure to

options.name: C
options.content: dependence on

options.name: D
options.content: advancement in

questions.article: The arrival of humans to the Americas is thought to have ______ a sudden decrease in biodiversity throughout the continents. Although the extinction of species like the toxodon was likely the result of a combination of factors, from decreasing food sources to habitat destruction, most of these factors can be directly tied to the presence of humans.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: followed

options.name: B
options.content: prolonged

options.name: C
options.content: counteracted

options.name: D
options.content: triggered

questions.solution: 这段文字讲述了人类到达美洲被认为引发（triggered）了整个大陆生物多样性的突然减少。尽管像雕齿兽（toxodon）这样的物种灭绝可能是多种因素共同作用的结果，从食物来源减少到栖息地破坏，但这些因素大多与人类的存在直接相关。 题目是让选择一个最符合逻辑和精确的词或短语来完成文本。 选项A“followed”（跟随、继……之后），如果用followed，句子意思变成人类到达美洲之后生物多样性减少，没有体现出因果关系，A选项不准确。 选项B“prolonged”（延长、拖延），与生物多样性减少的语境不相符，B选项错误。 选项C“counteracted”（抵消、对抗），人类到达美洲不是抵消生物多样性减少，而是导致了减少，C选项不符合文意。 选项D“triggered”（引发、触发），准确地表达了人类到达美洲是导致生物多样性突然减少的原因，D选项正确。 所以正确答案是D。文中的实体信息有：美洲（the Americas）、雕齿兽（the toxodon）。

questions.article: Some robots such as Surena (developed in 2008) and COMAN (developed in 2012) are designed to resemble humans so that people will find it easier to interact with them. To this end, certain features such as the ability to respond to voice commands can help to create the comforting semblance of humanity, but a robot that appears too similar to humans can make people feel more unsettled than ______.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: soothed

options.name: B
options.content: indifferent

options.name: C
options.content: revolted

options.name: D
options.content: vindicated

questions.solution: 这段文字提到一些机器人，如2008年开发的Surena和2012年开发的COMAN，被设计得像人类，以便人们更容易与它们互动。为此，某些功能，如响应语音命令的能力，有助于营造出令人舒适的人性化表象，但一个看起来与人类过于相似的机器人会让人比感到安慰（soothed）时更不安。 题目是让选择一个最符合逻辑和精确的词或短语来完成文本。 选项A“soothed”（安慰、抚慰），与前文提到的机器人设计目的是让人感觉舒适相呼应，且与后文的“more unsettled than”形成对比，A选项正确。 选项B“indifferent”（冷漠的、不关心的），与文意不符，这里不是说让人比冷漠时更不安，B选项错误。 选项C“revolted”（厌恶的、反感的），程度过重，且与前文机器人设计的初衷和语境不相符，C选项不合适。 选项D“vindicated”（证明……正确、辩护），与文本内容毫无逻辑关系，D选项不正确。 所以正确答案是A。文中的实体信息有：机器人Surena、COMAN。

questions.article:
The following text is Rainer Maria Rilke's 1897 poem Evening (translated by Jessie Lamont in 1918).

The bleak fields are asleep,
My heart alone wakes;
The evening in the harbour
Down his red sails takes.

Night, guardian of dreams,
Now wanders through the land;
The moon, a lily white,
Blossoms within her hand.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It conveys the speaker's sense that he is alone while experiencing the evening.

options.name: B
options.content: It shows that the speaker would rather look at the fields than at the water.

options.name: C
options.content: It indicates the speaker's disappointment that other people dislike rural settings.

options.name: D
options.content: It explains why the speaker has woken up from sleeping.

questions.correct: It conveys the speaker's sense that he is alone while experiencing the evening.

questions.article: When people think of dinosaurs with feathers, they typically think of winged dinosaurs, such as the bat-like Ambopteryx. However, many dinosaurs that didn't have wings also had feathers on their bodies. For instance, research indicates that the wingless, large Yutyrannus likely had feathers.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To discuss the presence of feathers on certain types of dinosaurs

options.name: B
options.content: To point out the differences between dinosaur feathers and bird feathers

options.name: C
options.content: To explain why feathered dinosaurs went extinct

options.name: D
options.content: To argue that only one species of dinosaur had feathers

questions.correct: To discuss the presence of feathers on certain types of dinosaurs

questions.article:
Text 1

In 2017 Buenaventura, Colombia, was named a City of Gastronomy by UNESCO in recognition of the city's unique food culture. The honor is well known among residents of the city as well as tourists who visit. It's obvious that the selection of Buenaventura by UNESCO has brought awareness to local recipes, cooking practices, and chefs and has provided a boost to the city's tourism industry.

Text 2

Many people in Buenaventura's restaurant industry hoped that food tourism would increase after the city was chosen as City of Gastronomy in 2017. However, as researcher Eerang Park and colleagues argue, cities must still create effective marketing strategies to benefit fully from being named a City of Gastronomy. Without an intentional effort to promote the city's food scene, many current and potential visitors to Buenaventura may not even be aware that it's home to uniquely delicious food.
questions.question: Based on the texts, what would the author of Text 2 most likely say in response to the underlined claim in Text 1?

options.name: A
options.content: A city that UNESCO officially names as a City of Gastronomy should still make deliberate efforts to attract visitors [in order to boost] tourism.

options.name: B
options.content: Many people worked together to help Buenaventura be recognized by UNESCO, but chefs deserve the most credit for Buenaventura's selection as a City of Gastronomy.

options.name: C
options.content: There are other benefits to being named a UNESCO City of Gastronomy besides increased tourism.

options.name: D
options.content: The naming of Buenaventura as a City of Gastronomy was long overdue, given the city's delicious food.

questions.correct: A city that UNESCO officially names as a City of Gastronomy should still make deliberate efforts to attract visitors [in order to boost] tourism.

questions.article: In a study by Mika R. Moran, Daniel A. Rodriguez, and colleagues, residents of Panama City, Panama, and Fortaleza, Brazil, were surveyed about parks in their cities. Of the 318 respondents from Panama City, 53.5% indicated that they use the city's parks, and of 938 respondents from Fortaleza, 35.7% indicated using city parks. Given that the percentage of Panama City respondents who reported living within a 10-minute walk of a park was much lower than that reported by Fortaleza respondents, greater proximity alone can't explain the difference in park use.
questions.question: The text makes which point about the difference between the proportions of Panama City residents and Fortaleza residents using parks?

options.name: A
options.content: It was much larger than the researchers conducting the study expected.

options.name: B
options.content: It could be due to inaccuracies in the survey results.

options.name: C
options.content: It was calculated using sources that predate the survey.

options.name: D
options.content: It is caused by something other than the parks' proximity to the residents.

questions.correct: It is caused by something other than the parks' proximity to the residents.

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Daniel Defoe's 1704 nonfiction book The Storm.

The sermon is a sound of words spoken to the ear, and prepared only for present meditation and extends no farther than the strength of memory can convey it; a book printed is a record, remaining in every man's possession, always ready to renew its acquaintance with his memory, and always ready to be produced as an authority or voucher to any reports he makes out of it, and conveys its contents for ages to come, to the eternity of mortal time, when the author is forgotten in his grave.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: People are less likely to forget a message when they hear it spoken aloud than they are when they read it in print.

options.name: B
options.content: Unless a spoken message is delivered by a confident orator, it may be ignored.

options.name: C
options.content: Most authors have little hope of being remembered well past their lifetimes.

options.name: D
options.content: Words committed to print have a greater permanence than messages that are merely spoken aloud.

questions.correct: Words committed to print have a greater permanence than messages that are merely spoken aloud.

questions.article: The Far Side of the World, first published in 1984, is a novel in Patrick O’Brian's Aubrey/Maturin series, which includes twenty books plus an unfinished fragment of a twenty-first. Like the rest of the books in the series, The Far Side of the World has a rather abrupt ending, but the following book, The Reverse of the Medal, picks up neatly where The Far Side of the World leaves off. Thus, the sudden ending is only an issue if one considers the books as independent texts—the Aubrey/Maturin series is best thought of as a single incredibly long work, similar to other multivolume stories, such as John Galsworthy's The Forsyte Saga.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It is unfair that the Aubrey/Maturin series does not have the critical reputation of The Forsyte Saga, which has a similar structure.

options.name: B
options.content: The Far Side of the World and The Reverse of the Medal are [two] of the most complex of Patrick O’Brian’s [novels of the Aubrey/Maturin series] with unconventional structures.

options.name: C
options.content: The structure of each of the novels of the Aubrey/Maturin series suggests that the series should be considered a single continuous story.

options.name: D
options.content: Many readers find the Aubrey/Maturin novels to be remarkably entertaining despite flaws novels' structures.

questions.correct: The structure of each of the novels of the Aubrey/Maturin series suggests that the series should be considered a single continuous story.

questions.article: One student is writing an essay about four pyramids for a history class and wants to indicate how long ago each pyramid was built. Consulting the table, the student finds that the Tikal Temple IV was built ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the text?

options.name: A
options.content: 1,900 to 2,300 years ago.

options.name: B
options.content: 1,300 years ago.

options.name: C
options.content: 4,500 to 4,600 years ago.

options.name: D
options.content: 3,800 to 4,000 years ago.

questions.article: Life Among the Paiutes is an 1882 autobiographical narrative by Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins. In the work, Winnemucca directly addresses the reader to establish her authority and credibility, writing ______
questions.question: Which quotation from Life Among the Paiutes most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “My dear reader, I have not lived in this world for over thirty or forty years for nothing, and I know what I am talking about.”

options.name: B
options.content: “I was born somewhere near 1844, but am not sure of the precise time.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Oh, dear readers, these soldiers had gone only sixty miles away to Muddy Lake, where my people were then living and fishing.”

options.name: D
options.content: “But how can I describe the scene that followed? Some of you, dear readers, can imagine.”

questions.correct: “My dear reader, I have not lived in this world for over thirty or forty years for nothing, and I know what I am talking about.”

questions.article: The Underdogs is a 1915 novel by Mariano Azuela, originally written in Spanish. In the novel, the town of Juchipila is depicted as a striking sight for a group of soldiers as they view it from afar: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from a translation of The Underdogs most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “All day long [the soldiers] rode through the canyon, up and down the steep, round hills, dirty and bald as a man's head, hill after hill in endless succession.”

options.name: B
options.content: “[The soldiers] entered the streets of Juchipila as the church bells rang, loud and joyfully, with that peculiar tone that thrills every mountaineer.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Juchipila arose in the distance, white, bathed in sunlight, shining in the midst of a thick forest at the foot of a proud, lofty mountain.”

options.name: D
options.content: “The sierra is clad in gala colors. Over its inaccessible peaks the opalescent fog settles like a snowy veil on the forehead of a bride.”

questions.correct: “Juchipila arose in the distance, white, bathed in sunlight, shining in the midst of a thick forest at the foot of a proud, lofty mountain.”

questions.article: Hypothesizing that lullabies, characterized by their slow tempos, are universally calming to infants, Constance M. Bainbridge and colleagues played a lullaby sung in the Scottish Gaelic language and a non-lullaby sung in the Seri language to a group of infants. The team found that the infants' heart rates decreased more during the lullaby than during the non-lullaby. Since a decrease in heart rate is associated with relaxation, the team concluded that the lullaby relaxed the infants. Noting that reduced heart rate can also be associated with increased attention, one critic argues that instead, the lullaby simply attracted the infants' attention. Bainbridge and colleagues also measured pupil size, as pupils typically become larger when a stimulus captures a person's attention.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly weaken the critic's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Blinking, which indicates attention, was equally frequent whether infants were listening to the song in Scottish Gaelic or song in Seri.

options.name: B
options.content: Neither the Scottish Gaelic language nor the melody of the traditional Scots lullaby was familiar to infants in the study.

options.name: C
options.content: The infants' pupils were smaller when the infants were listening to lullabies than when they were listening to non-lullabies.

options.name: D
options.content: Parents of infants in the study chose the lullaby over the non-lullaby when asked which song they would use to calm their child.

questions.correct: Blinking, which indicates attention, was equally frequent whether infants were listening to the song in Scottish Gaelic or song in Seri.

questions.article: In the early 19th, ships in the British Royal Navy were ranked based on military strength. The system considered the number of a ship's cannons and decks. “First rate” was the highest ranking, and “sixth-rate” was the lowest ranking, followed by unranked ships. This ranking determined the size of a ship's crew: first-rate ships had between 850 and 875 crewmen, while lower-ranked ships had fewer. Two of the ships in the British Royal Navy from this period were the Dreadnought (98 cannons and three decks) and the Royal George (120 cannons and three decks). Of these two, only the Royal George was ranked a first-rate ship. It can therefore be concluded that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: the Dreadnought had between 850 and 875 crewmen.

options.name: B
options.content: all ships with at least 98 cannons were ranked as first-rate ships.

options.name: C
options.content: the Royal George needed a crew larger than 875 people in order to operate efficiently.

options.name: D
options.content: not all ships with three decks were ranked as first-rate ships.

questions.correct: not all ships with three decks were ranked as first-rate ships.

questions.article: When bees pollinate flowers, they may be exposed to insecticides, potentially affecting their nervous systems. Recently, Dr. Rachel Parkinson of the University of Oxford added the common ______ to a sucralose solution to examine the insecticide's impact on honey bees' ability to walk in a straight line.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: insecticide sulfoxaflor

options.name: B
options.content: insecticide, sulfoxaflor,

options.name: C
options.content: insecticide sulfoxaflor,

options.name: D
options.content: insecticide, sulfoxaflor

questions.article: Argentinian César Milstein was a biochemist whose work has been instrumental in the diagnosis and treatment of disease. Initially overlooked as insignificant research by the scientific community, ______ contributed to the detection and treatment of numerous autoimmune diseases.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: Milstein studied monoclonal antibodies in 1975; they

options.name: B
options.content: in 1975 Milstein studied monoclonal antibodies, which

options.name: C
options.content: Milstein's 1975 study of monoclonal antibodies

options.name: D
options.content: monoclonal antibodies were studied by Milstein in 1975 and

questions.article: At 1,006 meters, the Forth Road Bridge in the United Kingdom is one of the longest suspension bridges in the ______ the Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge in Turkey, at 1,408 meters, is even longer.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: world, but,

options.name: B
options.content: world,

options.name: C
options.content: world, but

options.name: D
options.content: world but

questions.article: Both Heinrich Böll and Camilo José Cela have been commended for ______ contributions to literature, perhaps most notably when the Swedish Academy awarded Böll the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1972 and Cela in 1989.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: it’s

options.name: B
options.content: their

options.name: C
options.content: its

options.name: D
options.content: they’re

questions.article: On the other hand, Newark Liberty International Airport, which ______ located in Newark, New Jersey, saw an overall increase in departing passengers over the same time period, from 16,704,844 total passengers to 23,171,827.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: is

options.name: B
options.content: are

options.name: C
options.content: were

options.name: D
options.content: have been

questions.article: Rising 11,371 feet above sea level, Mount Leuser ______ among the world's tallest mountains.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: is ranked

options.name: B
options.content: to rank

options.name: C
options.content: ranking

options.name: D
options.content: having ranked

questions.article: As an object-oriented computer programming language Kotlin is used by coders like Black Girls Code founder Kimberly Bryant to create programs by manipulating “objects” (that is, specifically defined variables or combinations of variables) into interacting with each other. Conversely Pascal, ______ in software development and educational instruction, is not an object-oriented language.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: to use

options.name: B
options.content: used

options.name: C
options.content: the use

options.name: D
options.content: using

questions.article: Fans of the film The Princess and the Frog (2009) likely ______ the commanding bass voice behind the character Dr. Facilier. It belongs to actor Keith David. The veteran actor has performed in everything from commercials to Broadway musicals, but he is most known for his voice acting.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: recognizes

options.name: B
options.content: has recognized

options.name: C
options.content: recognize

options.name: D
options.content: is recognizing

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Blackberries are fruits that contain ascorbic acid, an essential nutrient for humans.
  • Every 100 grams (g) of blackberries contains 21 milligrams (mg) of ascorbic acid.
  • Many animals can make ascorbic acid in their bodies, but humans cannot.
  • Humans must get ascorbic acid from foods, including fruits and vegetables.
  • Ascorbic acid is also known as Vitamin C.
questions.question: The student wants to specify how much vitamin C is in blackberries. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Many animals can make ascorbic acid, which is also known as vitamin C, in their bodies, but humans cannot.

options.name: B
options.content: There is 21 mg of vitamin C in every 100 g of blackberries.

options.name: C
options.content: Since humans cannot make vitamin C in their bodies, they must get this essential nutrient from foods like blackberries.

options.name: D
options.content: Blackberries contain vitamin C, which humans must get from food.

questions.correct: There is 21 mg of vitamin C in every 100 g of blackberries.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Music by Black Composers (MBC) project aims to inspire aspiring music students by archiving and sharing information about the music of Black classical composers.
  • George Theophilus Walker is a Black classical music composer included in MBC's Historic Composers Directory.
  • He was born in 1922 and died in 2018.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to set up a discussion of Walker's career for an audience already familiar with the MBC Project?

options.name: A
options.content: While George Theophilus Walker is considered a great composer, there are many more such composers included in MBC's Historic Composers Directory.

options.name: B
options.content: Born in 1922, George Theophilus Walker passed away in 2018 according to the MBC project.

options.name: C
options.content: Among the many talented figures included in the MBC project is classical music composer George Theophilus Walker.

options.name: D
options.content: The MBC project's Historic Composers Directory highlights Black classical composers of the past, such as George Theophilus Walker (1922–2018), in order to inspire music students to become the classical composers of the future.

questions.correct: Among the many talented figures included in the MBC project is classical music composer George Theophilus Walker.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Sister cities are pairs of cities that form social or legal partnerships to promote each other's cultures.
  • Previously known as “town twinning,” the concept of sister cities evolved in Europe after World War II as a way to repair bonds between cities.
  • Many cities in New York State maintain such partnerships with cities around the world.
  • Rhinebeck, New York, and Larreynaga, Nicaragua, became sister cities in 1989.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize the duration of Rhinebeck and Larreynaga's sister city relationship. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Since the end of World War II, sister cities such as Rhinebeck, New York, and Larreynaga, Nicaragua, have continued to form social partnership to promote each other's cultures.

options.name: B
options.content: As sister cities, Rhinebeck, New York, and Larreynaga, Nicaragua, have engaged in cultural exchange and partnership since 1989.

options.name: C
options.content: Larreynaga, which in 1989 became a sister city—or “twin town”—to Rhinebeck, New York, is located in Nicaragua.

options.name: D
options.content: Despite their distance from each other, the sister cities of Rhinebeck, New York, and Larreynaga, Nicaragua have enjoyed the same partnership as many other sister cities.

questions.correct: As sister cities, Rhinebeck, New York, and Larreynaga, Nicaragua, have engaged in cultural exchange and partnership since 1989.
